questions.question: Identify the index?
questions.explanation: composite statistic used to rank countries based on human development levels. It is calculated by assessing three key dimensions of human development: Life Expectancy at Birth : Reflects the ability to live a long and healthy life. Education : Measured by the mean years of schooling for adults aged 25 years or more and the expected years of schooling for children entering school. Gross National Income (GNI) per Capita : Reflects the standard of living and economic conditions in a country, adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP). Incorrect Options: Options B, C and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.question: Which of the options below aids in determining the severity of a disease?
questions.explanation: related to virulence, representing the killing power of a disease. It is calculated as the ratio of deaths to cases , without specifying a time interval, using the formula: CFR is typically used for acute infectious diseases (e.g., food poisoning, cholera, measles) but is less useful for chronic diseases due to the long and variable period from onset to death. The CFR for the same disease can vary across different epidemics due to agent, host, and environmental changes. Proportional mortality rate (Option A): Measures deaths from a specific cause relative to all deaths, not directly predicting disease severity. This option is incorrect. Incidence (Option B): Tracks new cases over time, not directly related to disease severity. This option is incorrect. Prevalence (Option D): Total cases at a specific time, not indicating disease severity. This option is incorrect. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg no.66

questions.question: In Sustainable Development Goal 3, the target 3.1 aims to reduce the Maternal Mortality Ratio by 2030 to_____ (per 1 lakh live births)?
questions.explanation: Mortality Ratio by 2030 to < 70 (per 1 lakh live births) "Transforming our world: the 2030 agenda for sustainable development" was adopted by the United Nations General Assembly on 25 th September 2015. It has 17 goals and 169 targets, including a specific goal 3 for health with 13 targets. Incorrect Options: Option B, C & D are incorrect Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition Pg 40

questions.question: What does the point labeled C denote?
questions.explanation: disease to the clinical disease stage. Incorrect Options: Onset of pathological changes (Option B): Onset of pathological changes occurs before the subclinical stage Usual time of diagnosis (Option C): Usual time of diagnosis varies and can happen at any stage. Exposure to etiologic agent (Option D): Exposure to the etiologic agent precedes the subclinical stage. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 13

questions.question: When quarantine was introduced in the 14th century for plague, how many days were people who were suspected to have the infection quarantined for?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - 40 days The term "quarantine" originates from the Italian word "quaranta," meaning 40 . In the 14th century, during the outbreak of the bubonic plague, authorities in maritime cities like Venice implemented a rule that ships arriving from infected ports had to anchor for 40 days before passengers and crew could disembark. This 40-day isolation period was chosen for religious and practical reasons, as it was believed to be long enough to determine whether someone had the disease. Public health strategies: Isolation separates individuals who are already ill and potentially infectious from others for the maximum period of communicability to prevent disease spread. It can occur either in healthcare facilities or at home, depending on illness severity and resource availability. It is a defensive strategy. Quarantine separates and restricts the movement of individuals exposed to a contagious disease for a maximum known incubation period, but not yet symptomatic to monitor for symptoms and prevent potential disease spread upon becoming infectious. Isolation and quarantine are examples of primary prevention. Social distancing is a public health measure involving maintaining physical distance and avoiding crowded places or gatherings. It aims to prevent the transmission of infectious diseases but applies broadly, not specifically to individuals already ill. Contact tracing is the process of identifying and monitoring individuals in close contact with an infected person. It is used to identify potential secondary cases and implement appropriate measures, such as quarantine or testing, to prevent further transmission. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Pg 132

questions.question: Which of the following indicators is the best to know the overall burden of disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Disability-adjusted life years (DALY) DALY (Disability Adjusted Life Years) measures disease burden by combining years lost due to premature death and years lived with disability. Disability Indicators: Quality-adjusted Life Years (QALY) (Option A) Quality and quantity of life lived. Assesses number of years of life added due to the intervention and hence the benefit and value for money of the intervention QALY - 1 year of life lived in perfect health Positive indicator of the cost-effectiveness of an intervention. Scored between 0 (death) and 1 (perfect health). Disability-adjusted Life Years (DALY) DALY= Years of life lost to premature death + years lived with disability 1 DALY: 1 year of healthy life lost It is a measure of the burden of disease and the effectiveness of intervention Year of life lost (YLL): Calculated from the number of deaths at each age multiplied by the expected remaining years of life according to a global standard life expectancy. Years lost to disability (YLD): Where the number of incident cases due to injury and illness is multiplied by the average duration of the disease and a weighting factor reflecting the severity of the disease on a scale from 0 (perfect health) to 1 (dead). DALY = YLL + YLD Health Adjusted Life Expectancy (HALE) (Option B) The average number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health considering the current age-specific mortality rate. Healthy Life Expectancy HALE = Life Expectancy at birth + adjustment of time spent in poor health HALE = LE-DALY Life Expectancy Average no. of years a newborn is expected to live, considering the current age-specific mortality rate. Sullivan’s index (or DFLE) (Option D) Disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) with the current pattern of mortality and disability. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th ed pg 26

questions.question: A public health worker is going out into the community once every 15 days for collection of blood smears for malaria surveillance. What type of surveillance is this?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Active Active surveillance involves proactive efforts to collect data. In the scenario, the worker regularly collects blood smears for malaria surveillance, indicating proactive data collection. Surveillance is the systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of health data to plan, implement, and evaluate public health practice. Types: Passive Surveillance: relies on routine reporting from healthcare providers or institutions without additional efforts to enhance reporting (Option C) Active Surveillance involves proactive data collection, where health authorities actively search for cases of diseases. The 4 diseases that are actively screened in India: Polio: AFP (Acute Flaccid Paralysis) by SMO (Senior Medical Officer) Malaria: By MPW (Multipurpose Worker) Kala Azar (Visceral Leishmaniasis): Depending on the region or program specifics, various healthcare personnel may be involved in the surveillance and reporting. Tuberculosis: By ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) worker Sentinel Surveillance involves monitoring a specific subset of the population or healthcare facilities representing the larger population. E.g., HIV/AIDS screening done in ANC, Blood banks, and STD Clinics (Option A) Syndromic surveillance monitors non-specific health indicators or syndromes (e.g., fever surveillance for malaria, cough for 2w for TB, Flu symptoms for COVID) to detect potential outbreaks or public health emergencies early, analyzing symptom data patterns. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Pg 47

questions.question: Match the following stages with their relevant descriptions: 1. Pre-pathogenesis a. Normal course without any intervention 2. Pathogenesis b. Appearance of clinical signs and symptoms 3. Natural history of a disease c. Reaching normalcy with the help of the community 4. Rehabilitation d. Period before the onset of the disease
questions.explanation: symptoms of the disease. It's the stage before any pathogenic agents have affected the individual. Pathogenesis (2-b) : This stage involves the development of the disease after exposure to the causative agent, and it is marked by the appearance of clinical signs and symptoms. Natural history of a disease (3-a) : This refers to the normal course of the disease without any intervention, from its initial exposure to its potential resolution or progression. Rehabilitation (4-c) : Rehabilitation refers to the process of reaching normalcy or improving function with the help of the community or medical interventions after the disease has caused some impact. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page 41, 42, 51

questions.question: Which of the following explains Social factors and disease causation ?
questions.explanation: Options: Option A - Sociology: Studies social behavior but not disease causation. Option C - Society: Influences health outcomes but not a field of study for disease causation. Option D - Community: Important for health outcomes but not a specific field for disease Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.explanation: Minimum Maximum MYS (mean years of schooling) 0 y 13.1 y Expected years of schooling 0 y 18 y Education index 0 0.978 Income (PPP) 100 107,721 Live expectancy at birth 20 y 83.4 y Combination of indicators PQLI HDI 0 < PQLI < 100 0 < HDI < +1 India 65 India 0.640 .5 to .8 is medium country development Incorrect Options: Option A - QALY: Measures effectiveness of medical interventions. Option B - DALY: Measures disease burden. Option D - HPI: Measures poverty in developing nations. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A 35-year-old man is unemployed because he is unable to walk after an accident . His unemployment is classified as a:
questions.explanation: Incorrect Options: Option A - Disability: Doesn't address his inability to work. Option C - Disease/disorder: Focuses on illness rather than work limitation. Option D - Impairment: Doesn't specify work limitation. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: According to the NACO guidelines, what level of prevention is achieved when an HIV patient undergoes counselling and screening for TB at an ICTC clinic?
questions.explanation: secondary prevention measures for TB screening at ICTC clinics for HIV patients. Primary prevention involves counseling to address risk factors. Secondary prevention entails screening for early diagnosis and treatment. Incorrect Options: Option A - Primordial: Not applicable. Option B - Primary prevention: Incomplete; counseling also serves as secondary prevention. Option C - Secondary prevention: Incomplete; screening also serves as primary prevention. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A government plans to outline tobacco control laws. What is the level of prevention here?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Primary prevention Explanation: The government's plan to outline tobacco control laws is considered primary prevention because the laws are intended to prevent the initiation of tobacco use and thereby reduce the risk of diseases associated with tobacco use, such as cancer, heart disease, and respiratory conditions. Primary prevention focuses on reducing risk factors before any disease or injury occurs. Tobacco control laws aim to prevent the onset of smoking-related health problems by discouraging the use of tobacco. Primordial prevention (Option A): is incorrect because primordial prevention focuses on preventing the development of risk factors in the first place, like promoting a healthy environment or addressing social determinants. While tobacco control laws aim to prevent smoking, they are more specifically aimed at reducing existing risk factors (tobacco use), making primary prevention a more accurate term. Secondary prevention (Option C): is incorrect because secondary prevention focuses on early detection and intervention after the risk factors have been established. Tobacco control laws, however, aim to prevent the risk factor (tobacco use) from even emerging. Tertiary prevention (Option D): is incorrect because tertiary prevention deals with management and rehabilitation of individuals who already have diseases or conditions, which is not the focus of tobacco control laws. These laws are intended to prevent the occurrence of tobacco-related diseases in the first place. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 26, Page 48, 49

questions.question: Hand washing during COVID-19 is what level of prevention?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Primary prevention Explanation: Handwashing during COVID-19 is a form of primary prevention because it aims to prevent the onset of illness by reducing the risk of infection . Primary prevention involves actions taken to prevent the occurrence of disease or injury before it happens, and hand hygiene is an effective strategy to reduce transmission of the virus. Primordial prevention (Option A): is incorrect because primordial prevention focuses on preventing the emergence of risk factors for disease, such as promoting healthy behaviors in early childhood or ensuring access to a healthy environment. Handwashing is a more immediate preventive measure rather than an early-stage intervention. Secondary prevention (Option C): is incorrect because secondary prevention focuses on early detection and screening for disease, as well as early intervention to reduce the severity or complications of an already established disease. Handwashing prevents disease transmission, not early disease detection. Tertiary prevention (Option D): is incorrect because tertiary prevention deals with the management and rehabilitation of individuals with already established diseases to prevent further complications and improve quality of life. Handwashing is not related to disease management but to prevention. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 26, Page 48, 49.

questions.question: The years of potential life lost could be attributed to:

options.B: Years lost due to premature death
options.D: Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Years lost due to premature death Explanation: Years of potential life lost due to premature death. Example: If a 30-year-old dies, potentially losing 45 years of life (assuming a life expectancy of 75). YPLL is a mortality indicator, less sensitive in developed nations with better disease control. Mortality indicators: Crude death rate CDR = (Total no. or deaths in a community/ MYP (Mid-year population) in the same area) x 100 The mid-year population is taken on 1st July Limitation: It does not consider the age and sex of the population Age-specific death rate ASDR = (Total no. of deaths in a particular age group (eg. 20-24yrs) a given area in a year/ MYP of the age group in the same area and year) x 1000 Expectation of life Life expectancy at birth: A positive mortality indicator· Average no. of years a newborn is expected to live, considering the current age-specific mortality rates in a community. Important component to calculate the Human Development Index (HDI). Life expectancy at one year is PQLI. In 2021, life expectancy in India is 69.7 years . Infant mortality rate IMR = (Total number of deaths (0-1-year-old) in a given year / Total number of live births in the same year) x 1000. It is a health status indicator. Under-five mortality rate U5MR = (Total number of deaths (0-5 years old) in a given year /Total number of live births in one year) x 1000 Maternal Mortality Rate Maternal Mortality Rate (MMR) = (Total no. of maternal deaths/women in the reproductive age group [15-49 years]) x 100,000 Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) = (Total no. of maternal deaths/Live Births) x 100,000 Adult mortality rate Probability of dying between 15 to 60 years of life Year of potential life lost Premature death measurement. If life expectancy is 75 years, and death happens at age 30, then 45 years of potential life is lost Proportional mortality rate The simplest measure of the burden of disease (Total deaths due to disease 'x'/ Total deaths in a community) I x 100 Case fatality rate CFR = (Deaths due to diseases ‘z’ / total no of cases of disease ‘z’) x 100 Disability Indicators: Quality-adjusted Life Years (QALY) (Option D ruled out) Quality and quantity of life lived. Assesses number of years of life added due to the intervention and hence the benefit and value for money of the intervention QALY - 1 year of life lived in perfect health Positive indicator of the cost-effectiveness of an intervention. Scored between 0 (death) and 1 (perfect health). Disability-adjusted Life Years (DALY) (Option C ruled out) DALY= Years of life lost to premature death + years lived with disability 1 DALY: 1 year of healthy life lost It is a measure of the burden of disease and the effectiveness of intervention Year of life lost (YLL): Calculated from the number of deaths at each age multiplied by the expected remaining years of life according to a global standard life expectancy. Years lost to disability (YLD): Where the number of incident cases due to injury and illness is multiplied by the average duration of the disease and a weighting factor reflecting the severity of the disease on a scale from 0 (perfect health) to 1 (dead). DALY = YLL + YLD Health Adjusted Life Expectancy (HALE) The average number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health considering the current age-specific mortality rate. Healthy Life Expectancy HALE = Life Expectancy at birth + adjustment of time spent in poor health HALE = LE-DALY Life Expectancy Average no. of years a newborn is expected to live, considering the current age-specific mortality rate. Sullivan’s index (or DFLE) Disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) with the current pattern of mortality and disability. Years lost to morbidity (Option A): YPLL refers to

questions.question: What level of prevention is being addressed by administering an injection of benzathine penicillin to a patient with rheumatic heart disease?
questions.explanation: disease early before it causes significant complications. Administering benzathine penicillin to a patient with rheumatic heart disease falls under secondary prevention as it is taken to prevent further complications and worsening of the condition, which is already present but not yet leading to serious complications. Level of Prevention Goals Examples Primordial (Option A ruled out) To prevent the establishment of risk factors Lifestyle modification Health promotion Primary (Option B ruled out) Interventions to prevent the onset of disease Vaccinations Health education Family planning Use of mosquito nets Pre-placement examination Secondary (Option C) Early detection and prompt treatment of disease to prevent complications Screening tests (e.g., mammograms, PAP smears) Self-examinations Health camps with screening DOTS for TB; ART for HIV; MDT for leprosy. Tertiary (Option D ruled out) Interventions to manage and reduce complications of existing disease to prevent disability or death Rehabilitation Physical therapy Chronic disease management programs Reconstructive surgery Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 13

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the global hunger index?
questions.explanation: include the Infant mortality rate. It measures three dimensions of hunger: Food availability (Option C) , Child's nutritional status (Option B) and Child mortality due to undernutrition It includes three equally weighted indicators: The proportion of people who are food energy-deficient (FAO estimates) Prevalence of underweight children under 5 years (WHO data) Mortality rate of children under 5 years (UNICEF reports) (Option A) Reference: https://www.who.int/data/nutrition/nlis/info/global-hunger-index-(ghi)

questions.question: Which of the following diseases has the maximum submerged portion of the iceberg?
questions.explanation: a large number of infected individuals may be asymptomatic or exhibit mild symptoms, resulting in underreporting and unrecognized cases. This large reservoir of mild or asymptomatic cases contributes significantly to the spread of the disease. Incorrect Options: Option B - Chickenpox: Like influenza, chickenpox can have a large submerged portion where mild or atypical cases go unreported, especially in individuals with prior immunity or vaccination. However, most cases present with recognizable symptoms like rash. Option C - Tetanus: Tetanus has a small submerged portion because it generally presents with noticeable and severe symptoms. It does not spread from person to person, so there is no asymptomatic carrier state contributing to its epidemiological iceberg. Option D - Rabies: Rabies has the least submerged portion of the iceberg because it is almost always symptomatic and progresses to severe outcomes once symptoms appear. Nearly all cases are identified due to the seriousness of the disease.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a primary level of prevention for specific protection?
questions.explanation: protection. It's crucial for general hygiene but doesn't target preventing a specific disease. Incorrect Options: Option A - Meningitis prophylaxis: Provides preventive treatment to close contacts to stop meningitis spread. Option C - Vaccination: Administering vaccines prevents targeted diseases. Option D - Iron fortification: Adding iron to food prevents iron deficiency anaemia. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: On Republic Day, a medical camp was held to screen individuals for hypertension (HTN) by measuring their blood pressure (BP) and for diabetes mellitus (DM) by assessing their body mass index (BMI) and blood sugar level. The purpose of this camp was to determine the level of prevention.
questions.explanation: complications. Screening for hypertension (HTN) and diabetes mellitus (DM) aims to detect undiagnosed conditions. Goal is to provide early intervention and prevent disease progression. Incorrect Options: Option A - Primary: Focuses on preventing disease occurrence. Includes promoting healthy lifestyles and immunizations. Not relevant to screening for existing conditions (HTN and DM). Option B - Primordial: Aims to prevent risk factors for diseases. Addresses underlying social factors contributing to risk factor emergence. Not applicable to screening for existing conditions. Option D - Tertiary: Involves managing diagnosed diseases. Aims to reduce disease impact and improve quality of life. Differs from screening for undiagnosed conditions. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Vaccination & Mass chemoprophylaxis represent
questions.explanation: targets specific diseases to prevent occurrence. Incorrect Options: Option A - Health promotion: Encourages overall well-being. Option C - Early diagnosis and treatment: Focuses on timely medical intervention. Option D - Rehabilitation: Aims to restore functional abilities post-illness.

options.A: It is inserted by withdrawal technique
