questions.explanation: Copper T is designed to provide contraception for an extended period. Depending on the specific type of Copper T used, it typically has a lifespan of 10 years for CuT380A. 2nd generation IUDs Type Copper containing device Mechanism of action Reduces sperm motility and survival alters cervical mucus affects uterine enzymes increases cellular response in endometrium Features Strong anti-fertility effect Low expulsion rate Easy to fit in nulliparous

questions.question: Which of the following is not included in the scope of modern family planning services?
questions.explanation: modern concept of family planning services. Incorrect Option: Option A .Proper spacing and limiting childbirth: It is a part of the modern concept of family planning services. Option B . Genetic counseling: It is a part of the modern concept of family planning services. Option D. Education on parenthood: It is a part of the modern concept of family planning services. Reference: Ref: Park’s textbook of preventive medicine, edition: 25

questions.question: A female presents at 22 weeks of pregnancy due to rape. Which statement is correct regarding medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)?

options.A: Between 20-24 weeks, one doctor’s opinion is required
options.B: Between 20-24 weeks, MTP is only done if it is life-saving for the mother
options.C: MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in this case
options.D: MTP can be done after 24 weeks.

questions.explanation: this case: According to the amended MTP Act, 2021, MTP is permitted up to 24 weeks in cases of rape, with the opinion of two doctors. Incorrect Options: Option A - Between 20-24 weeks, one doctor’s opinion is required: Under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act, 2021, for pregnancies between 20-24 weeks, the opinion of two doctors is required, not just one. This applies to specific categories, including survivors of sexual assault. Option B - Between 20-24 weeks, MTP is only done if it is life-saving for the mother: While protecting the life of the mother is one consideration, MTP can also be performed during this period for other reasons, including if the pregnancy is a result of rape, or if there are significant fetal anomalies, without the need for the condition to be life-threatening to the mother. Option D - MTP can be done after 24 weeks: MTP beyond 24 weeks is generally not permitted unless severe fetal anomalies are detected that are incompatible with life, or if there is a threat to the mother's life or health. This requires the approval of a medical board.

questions.question: A couple approaches the doctor with a query regarding sexual precautions following the male partner's vasectomy procedure conducted a month ago. What guidance should be provided in this situation?

options.A: Oral contraceptive pills for 1 month for the woman
options.D: Hormonal treatment given for 2 more months for the man

questions.explanation: important to provide appropriate advice to the couple regarding contraception. Using condoms for 3 months helps to ensure that any remaining sperm are cleared and reduces the risk of unintended pregnancy during this period. After 3 months, the couple may choose to rely solely on the vasectomy as a contraceptive method. However, it is important to note that a follow-up semen analysis should be performed to confirm the success of the procedure and the absence of sperm in the ejaculate. Vasectomy is a terminal method of contraception done in males. It is a single time method, which does not require prolonged motivation for its effectiveness. Guidelines for Vasectomy: The age of the husband should be 25-50 yrs. The couple should have 2 living children. If the couple has 3 or more children, then the lower limit of age can be relaxed. Procedure: Postoperative advice: Must use alternate methods of contraception for 30 ejaculations (roughly 3 months) after the procedure to ensure sterility (option B). Should keep the surgical area clean Should not lift weights

questions.question: What is the most frequent side effect experienced by a 24-year-old woman of reproductive age who visited a rural primary healthcare center in India for the purpose of having an IUCD inserted to prevent pregnancy?
questions.explanation: is increased or irregular menstrual bleeding. Women may experience heavier or longer periods, spotting between periods, or irregular bleeding patterns in the initial months after IUCD insertion. This is a common and expected side effect that usually resolves over time. Side effects of IUDs Bleeding (Option D) Most common side effect ; physiological bleeding resolves in 1-3 months. Iron supplementation may be needed. Persistent bleeding despite treatment may necessitate IUD removal. Pain (Option C ruled out) Frequently causes removal; managed with analgesics. Resolves in 3 months. Severe pain may indicate uterine perforation (rare). Pelvic inflammatory disease (OptionB ruled out) Certain organisms reach the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries via the IUD thread. Presents with fever, abdominal pain, and discharge. Higher risk in women with multiple sexual partners. Requires broad-spectrum antibiotics; IUD removal if no improvement. Uterine perforation Rare complications linked to immediate postpartum insertion or poor technique. 1st generation IUDs are associated with a higher risk of pregnancy. Failure of contraception § pregnancy Least pregnancies are reported with MIRENA. If a woman requests an induced abortion – legally allowed. If a woman wants to continue pregnancy and threads are visible: Pull the thread and continue pregnancy. Explain the risk of spontaneous abortion or congenital anomalies. If a woman wants to continue pregnancy and threads are not visible: Uterus examination for any complications Evacuation of uterus if any complication is identified. Ectopic pregnancy (OPTION A ruled out) Recognized by lower abdominal pain, dark vaginal bleeding, or amenorrhea. Women at high risk should avoid IUDs. Expulsion Typically occurs within weeks of insertion or during menstruation; higher risk in young, nulliparous, postpartum women or using 1st generation IUDs Migration of IUD Rarely causes intestinal obstruction; diagnosed via X-ray imaging if suspected. Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th ed Pg 572-4

questions.question: A 25 year old female is using vaginal sponge as a barrier contraceptive during sexual intercourse. Which of the following Spermicide is used in contraceptive 'TODAY'?
questions.explanation: that is used as the active ingredient in many barrier contraceptives, including vaginal sponges, foams, gels, and creams. It works by immobilizing and killing sperm, thus reducing the risk of pregnancy. Nonoxynol-9 is the spermicide used in the contraceptive product 'TODAY'. Brand name TODAY Material Small polyurethane foam sponge Mechanism of action Combines barrier and spermicidal methods to prevent conception Saturated with 1000 mg of spermicide ‘Non-oxynol-9’ (Option C) Technique of use Must be run under water till thoroughly wet before insertion Inserted vaginally and must be ‘placed over the cervix to be effective Must be left in place for 6 hours after ejaculation All sponges must be removed within the time limits specified by the manufacturer (24 hours for Today) Disadvantages No protection from HIV or STDs May lead to Toxic Shock Syndrome if left beyond 24 hours Has to be left for 6 hours post ejaculation Increased risk of yeast infection and UTI Higher failure rate than diaphragm Failure rate Parous women: 20-40 per HWY Nulliparous women: 9-20 per HWY Incorrect Options: NET-EN (Option A): NET-EN stands for norethisterone enanthate, which is a progestin hormone used in some hormonal contraceptives, such as injectable contraceptives. It is not the spermicide used in the contraceptive product 'TODAY. DMPA (Option B): DMPA stands for depot medroxyprogesterone acetate, which is another progestin hormone used in injectable contraceptives, commonly known as the birth control shot. It is not the spermicide used in the contraceptive product 'TODAY'. Norethisterone (Option D): Norethisterone is a progestin hormone used in some hormonal contraceptives, such as combined oral contraceptives (COCs) or progestin-only pills (mini-pills). It is not the spermicide used in the contraceptive product 'TODAY'.

questions.question: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for the device shown in the image below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Vaginal bleeding The given image is of Copper T, an Intrauterine contraceptive device (IUDs). Vaginal bleeding is an absolute contraindication for the use of IUDs Contraindications to IUD insertion: Absolute C/I: Suspected pregnancy CA cervix, uterus, adnexa other pelvic tumours PID (active) Vaginal bleeding of unknown cause Previously diagnosed ectopic pregnancy Relative C/I: Anemia (OPTION A) Menorrhagia PID previously diagnosed Purulent discharge Uterine cavity distortion (fibroid, congenital malformations) (Options C, D) Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th ed Pg 572

questions.question: The duration for which copper T 380 A remains effective is referred to as its shelf life.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 10 years Explanation: Copper T 380 A is a long-term contraceptive device that remains effective for up to 10 years after insertion, making it a widely used option for long-term family planning. 3 years (Option A) : is incorrect because copper T 380 A is designed for long-term contraception, far exceeding a 3-year effectiveness duration. 5 years (Option B) : is incorrect because copper T 380 A provides contraceptive protection well beyond five years, although some other intrauterine devices have a 5-year lifespan. 7 years (Option C) : is incorrect because copper T 380 A's effective duration is specifically rated for up to 10 years by manufacturers and health guidelines. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 26, Page 576- 578

questions.question: All are given as emergency contraceptives except:

options.D: OCP 2 tab within 24 hrs, repeat dose after 14 days

questions.explanation: regular combined oral contraceptive pills (birth control pills) as an emergency contraceptive. While some regular birth control pills can be used as emergency contraception, the regimen described here is not a recommended or standard approach. Emergency contraception should involve specific doses of emergency contraceptive pills (like levonorgestrel or ulipristal) taken within the specified time frame. Regular birth control pills taken in this manner may not provide the same level of effectiveness as dedicated emergency contraceptive pills. Therefore, this option is not a recommended method of emergency contraception. Incorrect Options: Option A - LNG 0.75 mg 2 tab: LNG (Levonorgestrel) is a progestin-only emergency contraceptive pill commonly known as the "morning-after pill" or "Plan B." It is effective at preventing pregnancy when taken within a specific time frame after unprotected intercourse. The correct dosage is to take 1.5 mg of LNG (either as a single 1.5 mg tablet or two 0.75 mg tablets) as soon as possible after unprotected intercourse. This option is indeed an emergency contraceptive. Option B - Ethinylestradiol tablet: Ethinylestradiol is a synthetic form of the hormone estrogen, and it is commonly used in combination with progestin as a component of oral contraceptive pills (birth control pills). Option C - Ulipristal T: Ulipristal acetate is a selective progesterone receptor modulator that is used as an emergency contraceptive. It can be taken up to 120 hours (5 days) after unprotected intercourse and is more effective than levonorgestrel when taken closer to the end of the recommended time frame. So, option C is indeed an emergency contraceptive. Reference: Ref: Park’s textbook of preventive medicine, edition: 25

questions.question: Which type of cancer won't be affected if a patient uses OCP, which is a protective factor for?
questions.explanation: (uterine) cancer. The hormones in OCPs help regulate the menstrual cycle and decrease the exposure of the endometrial lining to excessive amounts of estrogen, which can contribute to the development of endometrial cancer. Incorrect Options: Option B: Cervical cancer OCP use does not directly affect the risk of cervical cancer. However, regular Pap smears and human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination are effective preventive measures against cervical cancer. Option C: Breast cancer The relationship between OCP use and breast cancer risk is complex. Some studies have shown a slight increase in the risk of breast cancer among current and recent OCP users, particularly in younger women. However, the risk seems to decrease after discontinuation of OCP use. The overall impact on breast cancer risk is relatively small. Option D: Bladder cancer OCP use is not known to have a significant effect on bladder cancer risk. Bladder cancer risk factors are more closely related to tobacco use, exposure to certain chemicals, and chronic bladder irritation. Reference: 1)Notes, 2) Ref: Park’s textbook of preventive medicine, edition: 25

questions.question: Spermicide used in contraceptive is?
questions.explanation: contraceptive methods. It is a surfactant that works by disrupting the cell membranes of sperm, thereby immobilizing and killing them. It is available in various forms such as creams, gels, foams, and suppositories. Nonoxynol-9 is typically applied directly to the cervix or inserted into the vagina before intercourse to provide contraception. Incorrect Options Option A: Gossypol- Gossypol is a natural compound derived from the cotton plant. While it has been studied for its potential contraceptive properties, it is not commonly used as a spermicidal cream. Gossypol's main use in contraception research has been focused on its effects on male fertility by inhibiting sperm production. However, its use as a contraceptive method is still under investigation and not widely available. Option C: Centchroman- Centchroman, also known as oral contraceptive pill (OCP) or Saheli, is an oral contraceptive medication. It is a non-hormonal selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that inhibits ovulation, alters the endometrium, and suppresses sperm motility. It is taken orally as a tablet and not used as a spermicidal cream. Option D: Clomiphene- Clomiphene is a medication commonly used in fertility treatment. It is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that acts by stimulating the release of hormones necessary for ovulation. While it is involved in the process of enhancing fertility, it is not a spermicidal cream and is not used for contraception purposes.

questions.question: Target couple is

options.A: Currently married couple where the wife is in reproductive age (15-49 yr. of age)
options.B: Eligible couples who have 2 – 3 living children

questions.explanation: couples who have 2-3 living children or even newly married couples to make them accept the idea of family planning. Incorrect Options Option A. "Currently married couple where the wife is in reproductive age (15-49 yr. of age)," is definition of eligible couple. Option C. "Couple using contraception," refers to couples who are already using some form of contraception. While they are part of the target population for monitoring and evaluation of family planning services, the term "target couple" generally encompasses a broader group of couples who are eligible for family planning, including those not currently using contraception. Option D. "Couple with 3 children," does not accurately capture the definition of a target couple. The number of children a couple has does not determine their eligibility or need for family planning services. Family planning aims to provide individuals and couples with the information, services, and methods to plan and space their pregnancies according to their desires and circumstances. Reference: Ref: Park’s textbook of preventive medicine, edition: 25

questions.question: Which contraceptive method should not be used in cases of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?
questions.explanation: formation of blood clots in deep veins, usually in the legs. Certain contraceptives can increase the risk of developing DVT. These contraceptives contain hormones, such as estrogen and progestin, which can affect blood coagulation and increase the risk of blood clot formation. Oral contraceptive pills (OCP): Oral contraceptive pills contain hormones, including estrogen and progestin. Estrogen, in particular, is associated with an increased risk of blood clot formation. Therefore, OCPs are contraindicated in individuals with a history of DVT or those at high risk of developing blood clots. Contraindications of OCP: Absolute: Cancer of the breast and genitals Liver disease Previous or present history of thromboembolism Cardiac abnormalities Congenital hyperlipidaemia Undiagnosed Abnormal uterine bleeding Relative : (Special problems requiring medical surveillance) Age over 40 years, or Smoking, and age over 35 years Risk of cardiovascular ffects increases with age and smoking. Go for progesterone-only pills. If she is a smoker, don't give combined pills if her age is over 35 years. Mild hypertension Chronic renal disease Epilepsy Migraine Nursing mothers in the first 6 months Diabetes Mellitus Gallbladder disease History of infrequent bleeding Amenorrhea, etc Incorrect options: Option A: IUD (Intrauterine device): The use of an IUD is not contraindicated in individuals with a history of DVT. IUDs do not contain hormones that affect blood coagulation. Option B: Condoms: Condoms are a barrier method of contraception and do not contain hormones. They do not increase the risk of DVT. Option D: No C/l (No contraindications): This option is incorrect because certain contraceptives, specifically those containing hormones, can indeed be contraindicated in individuals with a history of DVT or those at high risk.

questions.question: What are the absolute contraindications for intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs)?
questions.explanation: effective form of long-acting reversible contraception. While IUCDs are generally safe and well-tolerated, there are certain situations where they are contraindicated due to potential risks and complications. Acute PID (Pelvic Inflammatory Disease): Acute PID is an absolute contraindication for the insertion of an IUCD. PID is an infection of the reproductive organs, and the presence of an IUCD can potentially worsen the infection, increase the risk of complications, and delay appropriate treatment. Absolute Relative Pregnancy Anemia, Menorrhagia Recurrent PID History of PID Vaginal discharge of undiagnosed etiology Purulent cervical discharge Cancer of cervix, uterus or adnexa Distortion of uterine cavities e.g., congenital malformations, fibroids Previous ectopic pregnancy Unmotivated person Incorrect Options: Option A: Anaemia: Anaemia is not an absolute contraindication for the use of an IUCD. It may be a relative contraindication if the anaemia is severe and associated with significant symptoms, but it does not pose a direct risk for IUCD insertion or use. Option B: DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis): DVT is not an absolute contraindication for IUCD use. DVT is primarily a concern with hormonal methods of contraception, such as combined oral contraceptives, due to the increased risk of blood clot formation. IUCDs, which do not contain hormones, do not have the same associated risk of DVT. Option D: Endometriosis: Endometriosis is not an absolute contraindication for IUCD use. While it may cause symptoms and discomfort, it does not directly contraindicate the use of an IUCD. The choice of contraception in individuals with endometriosis may depend on various factors and should be discussed with a healthcare provider. Reference: .

questions.question: The most suitable contraceptive recommendation for a recently married couple is:
questions.explanation: several factors need to be considered, including effectiveness, convenience, safety, and personal preferences. While the choice ultimately depends on the couple's specific needs and circumstances, oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are often a suitable option for many couples. OCPs (Oral Contraceptive Pills): OCPs are a highly effective form of contraception when used correctly. They provide reliable pregnancy prevention, are convenient to use, and have additional benefits such as regulating menstrual cycles, reducing menstrual pain, and improving acne. OCPs can be started immediately and discontinued when the couple decides to conceive. Incorrect Options: Option B: Condoms: Condoms are a barrier method of contraception that provide protection against both unintended pregnancies and sexually transmitted infections (STIs). They are easily accessible, affordable, and do not require a prescription. Condoms can be a good option for couples who prefer non-hormonal methods or need STI protection in addition to contraception. However, they may have a higher failure rate compared to hormonal methods like OCPs. Option C: Sterilization: Sterilization, such as tubal ligation for women or vasectomy for men, is a permanent method of contraception. It is considered a long-term and highly effective option for couples who have completed their desired family size or do not wish to have biological children. Sterilization should be approached as a permanent decision, as reversal procedures are costly and not always successful. Option D: IUD (Intrauterine Device): IUDs are long-acting reversible contraceptives that offer highly effective contraception for an extended period. They can be a suitable choice for couples who desire long-term contraception without the need for daily or frequent user involvement. However, IUDs require a healthcare provider's insertion, which may not be immediately accessible for a newly married couple. Reference: .

questions.question: What should be the minimum rate of couple protection in order to achieve the demographic target of NRR = 1? NRR: Net Reproduction Rate
questions.explanation: to achieve an NRR of 1. While the exact required rate may vary depending on other factors, a couple protection rate exceeding 60% is generally necessary to achieve replacement-level fertility and an NRR of 1. NRR, or Net Reproduction Rate, is a measure used to estimate the average number of daughters that would be born to a woman over her lifetime, given the prevailing age-specific fertility rates. An NRR of 1 indicates that the population is replacing itself, with each generation being replaced by an equal number of offspring. To achieve an NRR of 1, it is necessary to have a couple protection rate that exceeds a certain threshold. The couple protection rate refers to the percentage of couples using effective contraception to prevent pregnancy. The higher the couple protection rate, the more effectively pregnancies are prevented, leading to a lower total fertility rate and potentially achieving an NRR of 1. Incorrect Options: Option A: 50%- This option suggests that a couple protection rate of 50% is required to reach an NRR of 1. However, this is not accurate. A couple protection rate of 50% might not be sufficient to achieve replacement-level fertility and an NRR of 1. Option B: 40%- This option suggests that a couple protection rate of 40% is needed to reach an NRR of 1. However, this is not correct. A couple protection rate of 40% might still be insufficient to achieve the desired replacement-level fertility. Option C: 70%- This option suggests that a couple protection rate of 70% is necessary to reach an NRR of 1. However, this is not accurate. While a higher couple protection rate increases the likelihood of achieving replacement-level fertility, a rate of 70% may be higher than what is required to reach an NRR of 1

questions.question: Which contraceptive method has the highest reported failure rate?
questions.explanation: spermicide creams, gels, foams, or suppositories, have higher failure rates compared to other contraceptive methods. They are generally used in combination with barrier methods, such as condoms, to enhance effectiveness. Incorrect option: Option B. Implant: Implants are highly effective long-acting reversible contraceptive methods and have a very low failure rate. Option C . Oral contraceptive pills: Oral contraceptive pills, when used correctly, are highly effective in preventing pregnancy and have low failure rates. Option D. IUD: Intrauterine devices (IUDs), both hormonal and non-hormonal, are highly effective contraceptive methods with very low failure rates.

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately reflects the truth about health propaganda?

options.D: It aids in developing a reflective behaviour

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) It appeals to emotions Explanation: Health propaganda is designed to influence or persuade people’s attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors regarding health-related issues. It typically appeals to emotions rather than logic, aiming to evoke strong feelings to drive action, such as fear, empathy, or excitement. It is actively acquired (Option A): is incorrect because health propaganda is often passively received through media, advertisements, and campaigns, rather than being actively sought out by the audience. It is behavior centered (Option C): is incorrect because health propaganda doesn’t primarily focus on modifying behavior directly but rather on altering perceptions or attitudes through emotional appeal. It aids in developing a reflective behavior (Option D): is incorrect because health propaganda tends to focus on immediate emotional responses rather than encouraging reflective, thoughtful behavior change that requires deeper cognitive engagement. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 26, Page 955

questions.question: What is the method employed to gather agreement on predictions among a substantial group of individuals?
questions.explanation: communication method that depends on a panel of experts. It involves gathering opinions from the panel of experts on a specific issue, summarizing their collective feedback, and repeating this process for several rounds. After each round, the experts share their feedback and the reasoning behind their judgements anonymously. This feedback encourages experts to reconsider and potentially revise their earlier opinions based on the responses of other panel members. Through this process, the range of responses tends to narrow, and the group will reach a consensus. The Delphi method does not involve participants discussing the issues or natural observation or statistical analysis. Incorrect Options Television (Option A): It is a medium for broadcasting information and entertainment to a wide audience (mass communication). It is not a structured method for gathering agreement or predictions from a group. Instead, it is typically one-way communication with no direct feedback mechanism to facilitate consensus. GATHER approach (Option B): It is employed in family planning counseling to offer supportive communication to clients when choosing contraceptive methods. Conferences (Option C): They are gatherings where individuals present ideas, research, and discussions. While they allow for the exchange of information and networking, they are not specifically designed to achieve structured consensus or gather collective predictions systematically. Reference: Use of Delphi in health sciences research: A narrative review - PMC https://www.aiims.edu/aiims/events/Gynaewebsite/ec_site/manual/1_3_1.htm Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Pg 983, 984, 993

questions.question: As a Medical Officer in charge of a Primary Health Center, you intend to engage in a conversation and address health concerns specifically with Antenatal mothers. What would be the ideal number of participants you would include in the focus group discussion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - 6-12 This range is generally considered ideal for a focal group discussion. It allows for a sufficient number of participants to provide diverse viewpoints and experiences, while still keeping the group manageable for effective facilitation and participation. Focus group discussion: Key Points Description Data Collection Technique Focus Group Discussion (FGD) is a qualitative method, in the form of two-way communication Participants 6-12 people seated in a circle, guided by a Moderator. Role of Moderator The active role of Leading the FGD by asking 10-12 open-ended, guiding questions. Sociogram Purpose Reflects the quality and interactiveness of the FGD. Sociogram Definition A diagram or chart created by an observer to represent the interaction dynamics during the FGD. Role of Recorder A separate individual is responsible for recording the discussion, with participants’ prior permission. Data Analysis Focuses on identifying common themes emerging from the discussion. Communication Style The FGD is interactive and two-way (Socratic), encouraging dialogue among participants and between participants and the Moderator. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition Pg 960, 961

questions.question: What is the term used to describe the act of disseminating a specific organized belief system or political perspective through the use of information with the intention of implanting it in people's minds?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Health propaganda Propaganda is information that is used to promote or publicize a point of view or a cause. Propaganda often has the connotation of being biased or misleading in some way-not telling the entire truth because of the need to promote a view, cause, product, or person. Health Education (Option C) Propaganda Mode of acquisition Actively acquired knowledge and skills (active thinking). Knowledge (may be false or exaggerated) is instilled in people's minds (facts). Develops Reflective behaviour. Trains people to use judgment before acting. Individuality. Personality. Self-expression. Reflexive behaviour. Aims at impulsive action. A standard pattern of attitudes and behaviours according to what would be used- a set pattern of behaviour. Appeals to Reason Emotion Knowledge acquisition By self-reliant activity Spoon-fed and received Process centered on Behaviour: aims at developing favourable attitudes, habits, and skills. Information: no changes of attitude- behaviour designed. Doctrine(Option A): simply means group or set of beliefs held or taught by a group. So, it is not something which can be used to spread a particular systemised doctrine itself. Health information (Option D): is any data related to a person’s health or disability including previous medical histories, injuries, signs and symptoms, etc. Reference: Park Textbook of Preventive Medicine 27th ed. Pg 987

questions.question: In India, which organization is responsible for promoting health awareness?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Central health education bureau The Central Health Education Bureau or CHEB is responsible for promoting health awareness in India. They develop efficient methodologies and training tools. Train critical health and community welfare personnel in health education and research approaches. They assist educational institutions for teachers and schools in their efforts to educate students about health. Central Health Education Bureau or CHEB: Has 5 divisions which are as follows: Media and editorial division Health promotion and education School health education division Training division Administrative division Central Bureau of Health Intelligence (CBHI) (Option A): is the health intelligence wing of the Directorate General of Health Services in the Ministry of Health & FW, Government of India. The Indian Council of Medical Research (Option B): (ICMR), New Delhi, the apex body in India for the formulation, coordination and promotion of biomedical research, is one of the oldest medical research bodies in the world. National Health Library (Option D): is not responsible for promotion of health awareness in India.

questions.question: The most effective approach to educating an urban slum community about oral rehydration solution (ORS) is -
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Demonstration The best method is to tell them the technique by showing them the technique. The demonstration is also known as two-way or Socratic communication. It relies on the principle of "Seeing is believing and learning by doing." It is one of the most efficient behavior change methods because it involves 'community participation.' Demonstration: is the best method for teaching practical skills, especially in low-literacy or semi-literate communities. It allows individuals to see how ORS is prepared and used, making it easy to understand and replicate. Visual and hands-on learning are highly effective for retention, especially when dealing with health practices like mixing the correct proportions of water, salt, and sugar for ORS. Reasons why the Demonstration method is highly effective in health education: (a) dramatizes by arousing interest (b) persuades the onlookers to adopt recommended practices (c) upholds the principles of "seeing is believing" and "learning by doing", and (d) can bring desirable changes m the behavior about the use of the new practice. Lecture (Option A): Less engaging, especially in communities with lower literacy or interest in theoretical teaching. Roleplay (Option B): Useful for Life saving skills, but less practical for teaching step-by-step processes like preparing ORS. Flashcards (Option C): Limited effectiveness in communities with low literacy and may not adequately convey the exact preparation technique. Reference: Park Textbook of Preventive Medicine 27th ed. Pg 992

questions.question: In a country like India, which is characterized by its varied cultures and languages, what measures should a physician adopt to effectively communicate with patients and ensure improved treatment results? 1. Insist on good communication 2. Insist on communication only via an interpreter 3. Treat them regardless of their cultural perceptions 4. The physician should consider the patient’s religion and cultural perception
questions.explanation: treatment, and patient satisfaction. A physician should prioritize clear, open, and empathetic communication, which is especially important in a diverse cultural and linguistic setting like India. The physician should consider the patient’s religion and cultural perception : Understanding and respecting a patient’s cultural and religious background is essential in providing holistic care. This consideration helps in building trust and in making informed decisions that align with the patient's values and beliefs, which can lead to better treatment outcomes. 1, 2 (Option A) : While insisting on good communication is essential, insisting on communication only via an interpreter may not always be the most effective approach, especially when interpreters are not available or when direct communication is possible in a shared language. It is better to attempt direct communication or use an interpreter when necessary rather than relying exclusively on one method. 2, 3 (Option B) : Insisting on communication via an interpreter and treating patients regardless of their cultural perceptions may not be ideal. Ignoring cultural perceptions can lead to misunderstandings and hinder the development of a good patient-physician relationship, which can negatively impact treatment outcomes. 3, 4 (Option C) : Treating patients regardless of cultural perceptions contradicts the idea of respecting the patient’s religion and cultural perceptions , which are crucial for effective care. Ignoring cultural perceptions can lead to suboptimal treatment and may even harm the patient’s trust in the healthcare system. Reference: Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page 918 Hutchison’s Clinical Methods, 24th Edition, Page 5, 6, 12

questions.question: ICER is a unit for which of the following economical analysis?
questions.explanation: (CEA). ICER is calculated as: ICER= Change in Effectiveness/ Change in Cost I Cost is measured in monetary units (e.g., dollars). Effectiveness is measured in health outcomes (e.g., life-years gained, reduction in disease incidence). CEA helps policymakers compare healthcare interventions based on cost per unit of health benefit. ICER is commonly used in health economics to decide whether a new treatment is worth its cost. Economic Analysis in Healthcare Health economic evaluations help determine the best use of resources by comparing costs and benefits of different interventions. Type of Analysis Measure Used Unit of Benefit Example Cost-Effectiveness Analysis (CEA) ICER Natural health units (e.g., life-years gained, infections prevented) Comparing two drugs for hypertension based on BP reduction Cost-Benefit Analysis (CBA) Net Monetary Benefit (NMB) Money Assessing whether a vaccination program saves more money than it costs Cost-Utility Analysis (CUA) Cost per QALY (Quality-Adjusted Life Year) QALY (Quality-Adjusted Life Year) Comparing cancer treatments based on survival & quality of life Cost-Minimization Analysis (CMA) Lowest Cost Option No effectiveness measure (assumes equal outcomes) Choosing between two equivalent generic drugs based on price Cost-benefit (Option B): Incorrect because CBA measures outcomes in monetary terms, not effectiveness per cost unit (ICER). Cost-utility (Option C): Incorrect because CUA uses QALY, not ICER, to compare interventions. Cost margin (Option D): Incorrect because "cost margin" is not a standard term in health economic analysis. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9561137/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8424074/

questions.question: Giving class in a village for wound care after a dog bite by enacting it is which mode of health communication?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Demonstration Explanation: Demonstration involves showing or enacting a process, technique, or skill in a visual and practical manner to the audience. In this case, by enacting wound care for a dog bite, the instructor is visually demonstrating the proper technique to the participants, making it an effective mode of communication. Lecture (Option A): is incorrect because a lecture involves verbally delivering information to an audience, typically in a one-way communication format, without the hands-on, visual demonstration of the technique. Group discussion (Option B): is incorrect because group discussion involves interactive exchange of ideas among participants, rather than a direct demonstration of a technique. Flash cards (Option C): is incorrect because flashcards are visual aids that are typically used to present information in a simplified manner, but they don't involve enacting or demonstrating a process like wound care. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 26, Page 959- 961

questions.question: The socially acquired learned behaviour is known as?
questions.explanation: acquired. Culture is passed on from one generation to another by learning process (bith formal and informal). Custom (Option A): Established pattern of human behavior. Customs are considered to be a part of culture as a whole. Socialization (Option C): It is the process by which individuals adopt the cultures, customs, traditions, beliefs, and habits of a society and become a part of the society. Mores (Option D): It is social norms that are widely observed within a particular society or culture. Mores determine what is considered morally acceptable or unacceptable within any given culture. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 785, 786, 787 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mores

questions.question: Which term refers to the practice of instilling a particular point of view in people's minds and inhibiting their independent thought?
questions.explanation: instilling a particular point of view in people's minds and inhibiting their independent thought. It involves disseminating information (may be false or exaggerated) that is designed to influence people's opinions and behaviors, often appealing to emotions rather than reason. Incorrect Options: Health Promotion (Option B): Health promotion involves activities aimed at improving overall health and well-being. Health Awareness (Option C): Health awareness is about raising knowledge and understanding of health issues among individuals and communities. Health Education (Option D): Health education involves providing people with accurate information and skills to make informed health decisions. It encourages active thinking and reasoning, aiming to develop reflective behavior and individual judgment. Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 967

questions.question: What is the ANMOL program for auxiliary nurse midwives?
questions.explanation: is a digital application for tablets designed for Auxiliary Nurse Midwives (ANMs) in India to improve healthcare service delivery. It is a mobile/tablet-based application developed under the National Health Mission (NHM). Features of ANMOL: Digital Data Entry – Helps ANMs record and update data of beneficiaries online. Real-time Tracking – Monitors maternal and child health, immunisation, and nutrition status. Paperless Work – Reduces the burden of maintaining physical registers. Decision Support – Provides alerts and reminders for due services. Integration with RCH Portal – Syncs data with the Reproductive and Child Health (RCH) portal for centralised monitoring. Benefits for ANMs: Increases efficiency in service delivery. Helps track pregnant women and newborns for timely interventions. Ensures accurate and up-to-date health records. ANMOL enhances maternal and child healthcare services by making data accessible, reliable, and easy to use for frontline health workers. Incorrect Options: Option B, C, and D are incorrect Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 281

questions.question: What significant error did the intern make while creating a banner on measures to prevent the spread of non-communicable diseases, as assigned by a group of doctors?
questions.explanation: recommendations and trans fats are not recommended in a healthy diet. Hence, this is the mistake made by the intern. Incorrect Options: Ban smoking in public areas (Option A): This is correct as smoking has health hazards for both active and passive smokers. Restrictions on alcohol selling/consumption (Option B): This is correct as consumption of alcohol can lead to liver disease. Decrease additive salts (Option D): This correct as additive salts could increase blood pressure. Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 472

questions.question: In the health education model, the first step is awareness; the second step is motivation. What is the third step?
questions.explanation: adoption of the message Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect, as given above.

questions.question: A patient does not understand the meaning of the doctor's words. Which type of barrier is this?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Linguistic When a patient does not understand the meaning of the doctor’s words , the barrier is due to language or communication issues , which is classified as a linguistic barrier . This may be due to use of complex medical terms, different languages, accents, or poor language comprehension. It impairs effective doctor–patient communication. Classification of Communication Barriers: Type Description Example Cultural Differences in beliefs, values, or customs A patient rejecting treatment due to cultural beliefs Linguistic Barriers related to language or word usage A patient not understanding medical terminology Psychological Related to emotions, stress, anxiety, or mental health A patient too anxious to listen or comprehend Environmental Due to external distractions like noise, poor lighting, or space A consultation held in a noisy hospital corridor Cultural (Option A): Incorrect – This would involve a conflict in beliefs or practices, not merely misunderstanding words. Psychological (Option C): Incorrect – This applies when emotional or mental states interfere with understanding, not language itself. Environmental (Option D): Incorrect – Environmental barriers refer to physical surroundings, not comprehension of spoken words. Reference: Park Textbook of Preventive Medicine 27th ed. Pg 984

questions.question: What is the main unit of administration in India called?
questions.explanation: India . Each district is headed by a District Collector or Deputy Commissioner, who is responsible for overseeing the administration, law and order, and development activities within the district. Districts are further divided into smaller administrative units such as sub-districts (tehsils) or taluks, which comprise multiple villages. Incorrect options: Option A. Village : While villages are an important part of India's administrative structure, they are not the principal unit of administration. Option B. Centre : The term "Centre" in Indian context typically refers to the Central Government, which is the highest level of administration in the country. the Centre represents the national-level governance. Option D. State: However, in terms of the principal unit of administration, the state level comes after the district level.

questions.question: Under the Factories Act of 1948, a social legislation aimed at ensuring the safety, health, and well-being of workers in their workplace, what is the prescribed limit for the maximum number of working hours per week?
questions.explanation: shall be allowed to work in a factory for more than 48 hours in a week. This includes regular working hours as well as overtime, if any. The Act also requires that workers get at least one day off in a week, commonly known as a weekly holiday. Incorrect options Options A, C & D are incorrect

questions.question: Regarding ASHA, all are true except:
questions.explanation: community health worker under the National Rural Health Mission in India. ASHAs play a vital role in providing primary healthcare services and promoting health awareness in their communities. They are trained to perform various tasks to improve the health of individuals and communities. ASHAs are not responsible for malaria slide preparation. Malaria slide preparation is typically performed by trained laboratory technicians or healthcare professionals. Incorrect Options: Option B: Ensure immunization as per schedule:This option is true. One of the key roles of ASHAs is to promote immunization and ensure that individuals receive vaccines as per the recommended schedule. Option C: Accompany pregnant women to the hospital:This option is true. ASHAs accompany pregnant women to hospitals or healthcare facilities for antenatal check-ups, delivery, and postnatal care. Option D: Spread awareness about contraception: This option is true. ASHAs actively engage in spreading awareness about contraception methods, family planning, and reproductive health. Reference: .

questions.question: In a community, an awareness session on handwashing was organized. The appropriate order of events in this session is:
questions.explanation: is:Awareness > Interest > Evaluation >Adoption Incorrect choices Options A, C & D are incorrect

questions.question: What is the term commonly used to describe a mode of communication wherein 4-8 speakers engage in a discussion on a specific topic in front of a large audience, without following a specific agenda, predetermined speeches, or a set order of speaking, and eventually interact with the audience?
questions.explanation: views on a given topic or problem in front of a sizable audience, without a set agenda, speech, or order of speaking, and with audience interaction at the conclusion. Incorrect choices Option b : Symposium - A symposium is an expert-led series of presentations on a particular subject or theme, usually more formal and structured than a panel discussion. Option c: Workshop - A workshop is a practical educational experience where participants learn new skills or techniques. series of more than 4 meetings. Option d: Seminar - A seminar is a lecture-style presentation where a speaker provides information on a particular subject, and the audience is then given the opportunity to ask questions or participate in a discussion. It may have a set agenda or speech.

questions.question: Which of the following is related to Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram?
questions.explanation: healthcare workers/medical officers in newborn care and resuscitation. Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram(NSSK) A training program launched by the Indian Government to equip doctors and nurses with essential newborn care skills, specifically addressing birth asphyxia. The ultimate goal is to reduce newborn mortality and morbidity. Goals/Objectives Reduce Neonatal Mortality Rate: Decrease India's Neonatal Mortality Rate to single digits by 2030. Improve Newborn Care Quality: Enhance the quality of newborn care. Prevent Perinatal Asphyxia-Related Issues: Reduce morbidity and mortality linked to perinatal asphyxia. Strategies Capacity Building: Equip healthcare providers with necessary knowledge and skills. Essential Newborn Care and Resuscitation Training. Updated Curriculum and Training Methodology Standardized Equipment and Supplies: Provide clean, functional equipment. Effective Knowledge and Skill Transfer: Improve practical application of training. Focus on "Golden Minute": Quick assessment and resuscitation. Promoting Clean Birth Practices: Adhere to WHO's "six cleans". Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC). Promotion: Encourage KMC for low birth weight babies. Timely Immunization: Ensure vaccination before discharge. Educate parents on newborn care. Effective Neonatal Transport: Establish protocols for the safe transport of sick newborns.

questions.question: Hyperpigmentation and keratosis can be seen with which of the following:
questions.explanation: hyperpigmentation, with dark patches or spots. It can also cause keratosis, leading to thickening and roughening of the skin. • This combination of symptoms is often referred to as "arsenicosis." Heavy metal Source of exposure Clinical features Lead Non-industrial Gasoline from automobile exhaust. Contaminated water from lead pipes. Lead paints in old homes. Industrial Battery and cosmetic manufacturing Printing paint and dye factories Glass manufacturing Shipbuilding Organic lead Wrist and/or foot drop. Insomnia. Headache. Mental confusion. Inorganic lead Anemia. Burton’s line - blue lines on gums. Colic, abdominal pain with diarrhoea/constipation. Arsenic (Option A) Pesticide Contaminated water Copper and lead smelting Wood preservatives Acute poisoning Gastroenteritis (Rice watery diarrhoea) Hypotension Non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema Proteinuria Seizures, delirium and encephalopathy Subacute poisoning (1-3 weeks) Glove stocking pattern polyneuropathy Absent deep tendon reflex Anemia, Leukopenia Chronic poisoning Raindrop pattern hyperpigmentation Palmar-plantar hyperkeratosis Alopecia Angiosarcoma Hepatomegaly Gangrene of extremities. Mercury Fish (from water pollution) Dental amalgam Gold and mercury mining Contaminated food and grains Greying of the oral mucosa Hemorrhagic gastroenteritis Acute tubular necrosis Shock Excessive irritability Acrodynia (painful extremities) Facial paresthesias Ataxia (loss of coordination), Dementia Blindness Cadmium (Option D ruled out) Smoking Paint manufacturing Nickel-cadmium battery manufacturing Plastic production Acute poisoning Inhalation: Pneumonitis; ARDS Ingestion: GIT hemorrhagic necrosis Chronic poisoning Osteomalacia Parkinson like symptoms Proteinuria Raindrop pigmentation (Arsenic poisoning) Acrodynia (Mercury poisoning) Copper (Option C): Overt acute copper toxicity presents with gastrointestinal symptoms like abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea, often with blue-green material in emesis/stool. Zinc (Option D): It is generally safe orally, but excessive intake may lead toxicity but hyperpigmentation and keratosis are not typical findings of zinc toxicity.

questions.question: According to WHO, what proportions of GNP should be spent on health services?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 5% Explanation: The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that 5% of a country's Gross National Product (GNP) should be spent on health services. This target is suggested to ensure that countries can provide adequate healthcare services, improve public health infrastructure, and address healthcare needs of the population. 2% (Option A): is incorrect because the WHO's recommendation is higher than 2%. The figure of 2% is often lower than the minimum threshold suggested by the WHO. 2.5% (Option B): is incorrect because the WHO recommends 5% and not 2.5% for a more optimal investment in the health sector. 3.5% (Option C): is incorrect because, although it’s a reasonable figure for some countries, the WHO’s recommendation is 5% , which is slightly higher. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 26, Page 20

questions.question: A doctor is consulted by a woman who is 8 weeks pregnant and employed in an industry. As per the ESI act, what is the length of maternity leave she is entitled to?

options.B: 28 weeks, starting from 4 weeks after delivery
options.C: 26 weeks, starting from 8 weeks before delivery

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 26 weeks, starting from 8 weeks before delivery Explanation: As per the ESI Act and Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017, eligible women are entitled to 26 weeks of paid maternity leave , starting from 8 weeks before the expected delivery date for their first two children. 4 months (Option A) : is incorrect because the ESI Act provides maternity leave benefits up to 26 weeks, not 4 months, and the 28-week clause is not applicable. 28 weeks, starting from 4 weeks after delivery (Option C) : is incorrect because maternity leave typically starts before delivery, not just after delivery, and the duration stated exceeds the legal limit. 9 months (Option D) : is incorrect because the ESI Act does not grant maternity leave for such a long duration. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 26, Page 911- 912

questions.question: In a hospital setting, the management seeks to determine the average duration of doctor-patient interactions in order to assess the need for adjusting the number of doctors. This adjustment is aimed at enhancing the quality of care provided. Which management technique would be most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Work sampling Work sampling is a management technique used to measure the proportion of time spent on different tasks or activities in a workplace setting. In the context of a hospital, it can be used to estimate the average duration of doctor-patient interactions by observing a random sample of interactions over time. This data helps in identifying patterns and making informed decisions about resource allocation, such as adjusting the number of doctors to improve the quality of care. Work Sampling: It is primarily used to systematically observe and record the activities of individuals at random intervals to estimate how time is allocated among various tasks , aiding in workforce management and efficiency improvement. It is used to evaluate how time is spent by healthcare providers like doctors, nurses, and pharmacists on different activities. It is a type of quantitative health management technique. Health Management Techniques Qualitative (Based on behavioural sciences) POCIMon Quantitative Personal management Cost-benefit analysis Organizational design Cost-effective analysis Communication Cost-accounting Information system Decision making Management by objectives PPBS - Planning, Programming, and Budgeting System Work sampling Network analysis System analysis Model (Option A): does not help in the above case. Decision making (Option B): one should consider the lower level needs and decisions, for example: Differential diagnosis in medical practice. Personnel management (Option C): includes looking after incentives and promotions. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine 27th edition Pg 1000

questions.question: Which of the following is assessed by evaluating the patient's treatment and clinical management in a healthcare facility?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Process Explanation: The Process of healthcare evaluation refers to the methods and actions taken during patient care. This includes the assessment of how the patient is managed, the treatments administered, and the clinical decisions made by healthcare providers during their treatment in a healthcare facility. Components of healthcare evaluation : Evaluation Type Description Focus Purpose Structure Evaluation (Option C ruled out) Assesses the resources and organizational components of healthcare facilities. Infrastructure, staff qualifications, medical equipment Ensure the healthcare facility has adequate resources, equipment, and trained staff. Process Evaluation Assesses how healthcare services are delivered, focusing on procedures and practices. Clinical guidelines, care delivery methods, patient interactions Ensure care is aligned with best practices and protocols. Outcome Evaluation (Option A ruled out) Evaluates the results of healthcare interventions. Health outcomes, symptom improvement, recovery, patient satisfaction Determine the effectiveness of treatments and interventions in improving health. Input Evaluation (Option D ruled out) Assesses the resources available for healthcare. Financial resources, staff levels, medical supplies Ensure sufficient resources for effective healthcare delivery. Cost-Effectiveness Evaluation Assesses whether the intervention provides good value for the cost. Cost relative to health outcomes, alternative treatments Ensure the efficient use of resources and value for money in healthcare. Patient-Centered Evaluation Focuses on patient experience and satisfaction. Patient satisfaction, provider-patient relationship, treatment understanding Ensure care aligns with patient needs and improves their experience and compliance. Components of health program evaluation: Component Definition Key Focus Areas Relevance Assesses whether the program addresses the priority health needs of the target population. Disease burden, target group needs, alignment with public health goals. Adequacy Evaluates whether the resources and scale of the program are sufficient to achieve the intended outcomes. Coverage, resource allocation, unmet needs. Accessibility Measures how easily beneficiaries can access program services. Geographic, financial, and cultural barriers to access. Acceptability Determines whether the program is acceptable to beneficiaries and stakeholders. Community participation, cultural compatibility, stakeholder feedback. Equity Assesses whether the program reduces disparities in health outcomes and services. Reach among marginalized populations, fairness in resource distribution. Efficiency Evaluates the optimal use of resources to achieve desired outcomes. Cost-efficiency, time management, operational performance. Effectiveness Measures the extent to which the program achieves its objectives and desired outcomes. Reduction in morbidity and mortality, behavior changes, program goals met. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 25, Page 946, 947

questions.question: Which of the following methods relies on the principles of behavioral sciences?
questions.explanation: sciences. Qualitative type of health management is based on behavioral sciences. It includes Personal management Organizational design Communication Information system Management by objective Incorrect Options: Option A, B & C are incorrect. Decision making, network analysis, and system analysis is Quantitative which is not based on behavioral sciences. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition Pg 997

questions.question: In which of the following analyses is the financial advantage quantified?
questions.explanation: outcome of a program in monetary terms. It compares the economic benefits and cost of the program. Incorrect Options: Cost-effective analysis (Option A): Cost-effective analysis measures outcome of a program in nonmonetary terms . Network analysis (Option C): A graphic plan of all events to be completed in order to reach an end objective. Input-output analysis (Option D): It is an economic technique. Monetary benefits are not measured in this technique. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition Pg 997

questions.question: What is the ultimate desired state towards which objectives and resources are aimed in the medical field?
questions.explanation: desired state that directs all objectives and resources. Not constrained by time and resources Timeframe guideline - should not extend beyond a five-year period. Incorrect Options: Target (Option A): It measures the degree of achievement of objectives. E.g. To complete the objective, i.e., increase immunization coverage by 60%., one needs to target conducting 1 health education session per week. Mission (Option B): It refers to the overall purpose or reason for the existence of an organization or entity. Plan (Option D): It refers to a detailed course of action outlining how specific objectives will be achieved. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Ed. Pg.no. 996, 997

questions.question: Which of the following is defined as the systematic observation and recording of activities of one or more individuals at predetermined or random intervals?
questions.explanation: observation and recording of activities performed by one or more individuals at predetermined or random intervals. It is a technique used in industrial engineering and management to gather data about how work is being conducted, how time is allocated, and how resources are utilized. Work Sampling does not involve calculating project costs or evaluating monetary benefits . It is primarily used to systematically observe and record the activities of individuals at random intervals to estimate how time is allocated among various tasks , aiding in workforce management and efficiency improvement. It is used to evaluate how time is spent by healthcare providers like doctors, nurses, and pharmacists on different activities. It is a type of quantitative health management technique. Model (Option A): It refers to a conceptual or mathematical representation used to simulate, predict, or explain real-world phenomena. This option is incorrect. Decision making (Option B): It is a cognitive process involving the selection of a course of action from available alternatives. This option is incorrect. Personnel management (Option C): It involves the administration of human resources within an organization, including recruitment, training, performance evaluation, and employee relations. This option is incorrect. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine 27th edition Pg 999, 1000

questions.question: NITI Aayog has replaced the?

options.B: National institute of health & family welfare (NIHFW)

questions.explanation: is National Institution for Transforming India. It replaced the planning commission on January 1, 2015. NITI Aayog is the organization responsible for developing the Health Index in India . The Health Index is a composite measure that tracks the performance of Indian states and Union Territories on various health indicators. Eg. Neonatal Mortality Rate, Under-5 Mortality Rate, etc. NITI Aayog replaced Planning Commission of India in 2015 , acts as a think tank to the central and state governments on policy matters, including health. The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare collaborates with NITI Aayog and provides data but is not the primary organization for evaluating and releasing the Health Index. The Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) focuses on biomedical research and is not involved in creating the Health Index. The World Health Organization (WHO) is an international body that provides health-related guidelines and support but does not develop the Health Index for India. Medical Council of India (MCI) (Option A): The MCI was a statutory body that regulates medical education. The MCI has been replaced by by the National Medical Commission (NMC) to enhance transparency and improve medical education standards. National Institute of Health & Family Welfare (NIHFW) (Option B): The NIHFW is an autonomous organization under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in India, the NIHFW has not been replaced by NITI Aayog. National Board of Examinations (NBE) (Option D): The NBE is an autonomous body responsible for conducting postgraduate medical examinations in India. The NBE has not been replaced by NITI Aayog. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine 27th edition Pg 32 & Pg 1002 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9896116/ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_Council_of_India https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Board_of_Examinations_in_Medical_Sciences https://nihfw.ac.in/

questions.question: Under which benefit in the ESI act do beneficiaries receive 70% of their wages for a duration of 3 months?
questions.explanation: 70% wages for 91 days continuously. An extended sickness benefit is provided for 34 diseases including TB, leprosy, HIV, and mental illness for 2 years at 80% of daily wages. Benefits of ESI (Employees State Insurance) Act Medical Benefit (Option B ruled out) Provides "full medical care," including hospitalization at no cost to insured individuals & families in cases of sickness, employment injury, and maternity. Sickness Benefit (Option A) Provides 70% of average daily wages in cash during medical leave for a maximum of 91 days within 365 days, as certified by the Insurance Medical Officer/Practitioner. Extended Sickness Benefit Extended coverage for long-term diseases beyond 91 days; 34 diseases covered if employed for two years. Extended sickness benefit is paid at 80% of the insured person's wages. Enhanced Sickness Benefit Cash benefits (100% wages) for sterilization procedures: 14 days for tubectomy (women), 7 days for vasectomy (men). Maternity Benefit (Option C ruled out) Cash payments for childbirth, miscarriage, or pregnancy-related sickness: 26 weeks for childbirth, 6 weeks for miscarriage, and 40 days for pregnancy-related sickness. Paid at 100% of the insured woman's average daily wages. Disablement Benefit Temporary Disablement Benefit (TDB): 90% of wages paid from day one for temporary employment injury, until recovery. Permanent Disablement Benefit (PDB): 90% of wages paid monthly for life, based on certified loss of earning capacity. Dependent's Benefit (Option D ruled out) Dependents receive 90% of the deceased's (due to employment injuries) wages as a shared pension, and they are eligible until age 18. If the daughter marries before 18, the benefit is withdrawn. Funeral Expenses It offers a cash payment of up to Rs. 15,000 to cover funeral expenses upon the death of an insured individual. Rehabilitation Insured individuals and their families are entitled to continued medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement. They have to pay a nominal fee of Rs.10 per month for this benefit. A rehabilitation allowance of Rs.15,000 granted. Unemployment allowance For eligible employees due to factory closure or retrenchment: 50% of wage for up to two years. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 943, 944 https://www.esic.gov.in/benefits https://www.esic.gov.in/information-benefits https://www.indiacode.nic.in/handle/123456789/1441?view_type=browse&sam_handle=123456789/1362

questions.question: The most accurate representation of maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for a nation is
questions.explanation: key indicator used to measure maternal health and assess the risk of maternal death during pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days after the end of pregnancy. It is expressed as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births. Incorrect Options: Option A. (Maternal deaths per 100 live births) is not as accurate because it does not account for the larger scale of live births, which makes it difficult to compare MMR between different populations. Option B. (Maternal deaths per 10,000 live births) is also not the best choice because it overestimates the MMR by using a smaller denominator (10,000) compared to option C. Option D. (Maternal deaths per 1,000 live births) is not appropriate either because it underestimates the MMR by using a larger denominator (1,000) compared to option C. Therefore, option C, which represents the MMR as maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, provides the most accurate and widely used representation of this indicator.

questions.question: What is the denominator used in the calculation of case fatality rate?

options.A: Total number of deaths due to all causes
options.C: Total number of cases due to the disease concerned
options.D: Total number of deaths due to the disease concerned

questions.explanation: correct denominator for calculating the case fatality rate. The case fatality rate is calculated by dividing the number of deaths due to the disease concerned by the total number of cases related to that specific disease. It provides a measure of the proportion of individuals diagnosed with the disease who die from it. Incorrect options Option A, B & D are incorrect

questions.question: Which of the following recommendations was NOT made by the Chadha committee?

options.C: One basic health worker per 10,000 population
options.D: Responsibility of PHCs in malaria eradication

questions.explanation: focused on the National Malaria Eradication Programme, did not specifically recommend one PHC for every 50,000 population. Instead, its recommendations were more focused on integrating malaria eradication activities into general health services, particularly at the PHC level. The exact recommended ratio of PHCs to population was not mentioned in the committee's report. Incorrect Options Option A: PHC at block level The Chadha Committee did recommend the establishment of PHCs at the block level. This recommendation was aimed at decentralizing healthcare and improving access to primary health services across different regions. Option C: One basic health worker per 10,000 population The Chadha Committee suggested having one basic health worker per 10,000 population to ensure that there were enough healthcare providers available at the grassroots level to carry out primary healthcare services effectively. Option D: Responsibility of PHCs in malaria eradication The Chadha Committee emphasized the role of PHCs in the National Malaria Eradication Programme, assigning them responsibilities in the detection, treatment, and prevention of malaria. This integration was part of the broader strategy to utilize existing healthcare infrastructure for disease control programs. Reference: ..

questions.question: Which of the following combination of biomedical waste management is correct regarding the disposal of an Expired tablet?
questions.explanation: expired tablets and pharmaceuticals, needs to be disposed of properly to prevent environmental contamination and health hazards. The correct method for the disposal of expired tablets is incineration, which ensures complete destruction of the pharmaceutical substances. Yellow bag - incineration: Yellow bags or containers are used for the collection of biomedical waste that requires incineration. This waste includes pharmaceuticals, chemicals, and other hazardous materials. Incineration is a high-temperature process that destroys the drugs, reducing the chance of environmental contamination. Incorrect Options: Option A. Red bag - hydroclaving: Red bags typically signify medical waste that is potentially infectious. Hydroclaving is a method that uses high-pressure steam to sterilize infectious waste, but it may not be the ideal method for pharmaceutical disposal, especially for large quantities like expired tablets. Option B. Blue bag - incineration: Blue bags are often used for recyclable materials. Incineration is the correct method for pharmaceutical disposal, but blue bags are not typically associated with biomedical waste disposal. Option D. Yellow bag - burial: Burial of pharmaceuticals or biomedical waste is not a recommended or acceptable method of disposal due to the risk of groundwater contamination and environmental pollution. Reference: .

questions.question: As per biomedical waste management guidelines, in which colored bag should used pacemakers be discarded?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Blue Explanation: According to the Biomedical Waste Management Guidelines , used pacemakers should be disposed of in the blue colored bag, which is designated for non-infectious, recyclable, and discarded electronics . The blue bag is typically used for items like discarded electronics , including pacemakers, that are not considered hazardous or infectious but need to be disposed of safely due to their electronic and metal components. Yellow (Optio A) : Yellow bags are used for infectious waste such as human tissues, body fluids, and soiled items. White (Option B) : White bags are typically used for glassware and items that are non-infectious but still require careful disposal. Black (Option C) : Black bags are used for general waste that is non-hazardous, but pacemakers are classified under non-infectious medical waste that needs special handling. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 27, Page 919

questions.question: Cytotoxic drug is disposed in:
questions.explanation: or chemotherapy drugs, are disposed of in a specialized yellow bag. These drugs are considered hazardous substances due to their toxic properties. The yellow bag is designed specifically for collecting and disposing hazardous or cytotoxic waste, including unused or expired drugs, empty drug vials, IV tubing, and other items contaminated with cytotoxic drugs. Color Type of waste Example of waste Treatment and disposal Yellow (Option A) Human anatomical waste. Animal anatomical waste. Soiled waste. Discarded or expired medicine. Microbiology, biotechnology and other clinical laboratory waste. Chemical waste. Chemical liquid waste. Placenta. Post-operative body parts. Plaster of Paris (POP). Pathological waste. Cotton waste. Dressing materials. Beddings. Body fluid contaminated paper and cloth. Face mask, cap, shoe cover and head cover. Cytotoxic, expired and discarded medicines. Microbiology and biotechnology lab waste. Blood bag Vacutainers with blood Incineration. Plasma pyrolysis. Deep burial. Red (Option B ruled out) Contaminated waste that is recyclable. Syringe without needles. Fixed needle syringes with their needle cut. IV set. Catheters. Gloves (soiled or unsoiled). Urine bag. Dialysis kit. IV bottles. Tubing's. Bottles. Vacutainers with needle cuts. Vacutainers without blood. ELISA plates and vials not containing blood samples. Autoclaving or microwaving/ hydroclaving followed by shredding or mutilation and waste set to registered recyclers or for energy recovery/road making. Plastic waste should not be sent to landfill sites. White Waste Sharps Needles Syringes with fixed needles Blades Scalpers Trocar cannula Insulin pen needle Puncture proof , Leak proof, Tamper proof containers Autoclaving or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding or mutilation or encapsulation in metal container or cement concrete Or sent for final disposal to iron foundries or sanitary landfills or designated concrete waste sharp pit Blue (Option C ruled out) Glassware or metallic body implants. Includes broken or discarded glass and metallic objects that are contaminated. Glass: Broken glass. Ampoules. Lab slide Metals: Nails. Metallic body implants. Scissors. Artificial pacemakers. Cardboard boxes with blue colored markings or blue coloured puncture-proof and tamper-proof containers. Disinfection (cleaning with detergent and soaking in sodium hypochlorite) or autoclaving or microwaving or hydroclaving and then sent for recycling. Black bag (Option D): Black bags are commonly used for general waste or municipal solid waste that does not require specialized handling or disposal. Similar to blue bags, black bags are not appropriate for the disposal of cytotoxic drugs due to their hazardous nature. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 918 - 920

questions.question: Which of the options below could have been discarded in the white bag by the compounder as biomedical waste?
questions.explanation: sharps. They are not pretreated and they are recycled or reused after shredding. Colour Waste Type Type of bag or container to be used Method of disposal Yellow All infectious waste. Human anatomical waste. (Option A ruled out) Animal anatomical waste Soiled waste (contaminated with blood, body fluids, dressings and swabs, blood bags ). Expired or discarded medicines Chemical waste. Microbiological and other clinical laboratory waste. Yellow coloured non chlorinated plastic bags. Incineration Plasma pyrolysis Deep burial Red Contaminated waste (recyclable) : Tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags , syringes (without needles), vacutainers and gloves. (Option D ruled out) Red coloured non chlorinated plastic bags. Autoclaving or microwaving/hydroclaving, and then sent for recycling (not to landfill). Blue Glassware: Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampoules except those contaminated with cytotoxic waste. (Option C ruled out) Metallic body implants . Cardboard boxes with blue coloured markings. Disinfection or autoclaving/microwaving, hydroclaving and then sent to recycling. White Waste sharps including metals: Needles, syringes with fixed needles, scalpels or any other sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. (Option B) Puncture proof and leak proof containers. Auto or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding and mutilation or encapsulation. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 918 - 920
